explanation:
The report is not correct as stated. BASE64Encode itself does not call any string.h functions (no strlen/memcpy/strncpy/etc.) and therefore cannot violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. Agent A’s described violation (strlen scanning past the end of the buffer) actually applies to ws_get_accept_value, not BASE64Encode.

In ws_get_accept_value the code does: if ((NULL == key) || (WS_KEY_LEN != strlen(key))) { ... }
This is problematic: strlen will scan for a NUL terminator and, if key is not NUL-terminated within its valid WS_KEY_LEN bytes, strlen may read beyond the bounds of the object — exactly the situation Rule 21.17 forbids. So the scenario described by Agent A is valid, but it is a violation in ws_get_accept_value (and also makes the subsequent strncpy calls unsafe), not in BASE64Encode.

Recommended fixes: use a bounded length check (e.g. strnlen(key, WS_KEY_LEN) and compare to WS_KEY_LEN), or ensure the caller guarantees a NUL-terminated buffer, or avoid strlen entirely and use a length-aware API (memcmp/memcpy or explicit length field). Also ensure bounded copies (avoid unbounded strncpy usage; prefer memcpy with known lengths or use snprintf/explicit termination).
